Alumni News

Sam Brickman ('17) is a junior at Cornell majoring in computer science. He is a co-creator of www.qtinebuddy.com, a website where you can find your quarantine buddy. . .Whether you want to find "the one," someone to start a company with, a Zoom yoga partner, or just someone to be bored with, your quarantine buddy's got you!

“We noticed that people were feeling more socially isolated more than ever right now, and we wanted to build something to help people where people are still feeling connected to one another while still social distancing,” said Brickman.

After completing a brief questionnaire, the site's machine learning matching algorithm will form the best possible "quaranteams." Then, users will receive a text with their buddy’s information so they can connect with one another virtually.

Quarantine Buddy launched April 1 and already has more than 6,000 users from 43 different countries signed up.

ICYMI -- April 1, 2020 was Census Day for the nation's once-per-decade constitutionally-mandated anonymous count of every person, regardless of their citizenship status.

New York State's fair share of the more than $800B in federal funds -- for programs essential to health care, housing, economic development, and transportation, as well as New York's congressional representation in Washington -- all depend on an accurate and fully-counted census response.

At the local level, the census count impacts the amount of federal dollars communities receive for school funding, special education, classroom technology, teacher training, after-school programs, school lunch assistance, and more.

The Chappaqua Central School District is just one of the many organizations seeking to raise awareness to have all of New York's residents counted in order to ensure adequate funding.

Thank you Chappaqua School Foundation, Inc. for the Instagrant to purchase the 300+ copies of "Night".

To honor the life, teachings, and legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Chappaqua's middle schools participated in a Day of Service that connected students to organizations that meet a need in their community.

This also was an opportunity to celebrate the multitude of service work students and families are doing outside of school hours, and this experience allowed those students to share out, possibly recruit others to join their efforts, and perhaps start something new.

Special thanks to everyone involved in making this year's day of service events come to fruition.

Bring the entire family to this updated production of Cinderella, which features Rodgers & Hammerstein's most beloved songs, including -- “In My Own Little Corner,” "Ten Minutes Ago" “Impossible/It's Possible” -- alongside a hilarious and romantic libretto by Tony Award nominee Douglas Carter Beane as well as some new characters, and surprising twists.

The October 25th meetup between Roaring Brook 3rd graders and LIFE school 11th graders in the "Physics & Chemistry of the Universe" class was fantastic!

This special event was arranged by Johanna Weidenhamer, who reached out Jenny Gieras, seeking an authentic audience for her juniors who were working on creating picture books for kids about the creation of the universe.

Students spent some time getting to know one another, then the older kids shared their picture books about the creation of the universe with the younger kids, which led to some great questioning, clarifying, and explaining.

Afterward, the 3rd graders showed the older kids the magnetic force projects they created as a culmination to a Science 21 unit on force and motion, and the Greeley students provided feedback and advice to the young engineers.

They concluded with a reflective discussion about creating for an audience, purposeful feedback, perseverance, and collaboration.

The New York State School Boards Association (NYSSBA) sponsors School Board Recognition Week -- October 21-25, 2019 -- to recognize school board members for their commitment to New York public school children.

Thank you Jane Kimmel Shepardson (President), Holly McCall (Vice President), Hilary Grasso, Warren Messner and Victoria Tipp for your dedicated leadership in public education and continuing service to the children of this community.

Chappaqua’s five Board of Education members are elected to a three-year term by district residents and receive no compensation. They are ordinary citizens who generously volunteer their time and energy to improve the education offered to students in Chappaqua while also balancing the cost to taxpayers.

Their tasks are substantial. They work together to establish a vision for the education program, design a structure to achieve that vision, craft policies, listen to student and staff concerns, assure schools are accountable to the community, serve on committees, and strongly advocate for continuous improvement in student learning.

The last thing you would expect to see on the first day of summer vacation is a full parking lot.

On June 27th, it was P.D. Done Differently as the Chappaqua Central School District hosted BaseCamp 2019, an un-conference that brought together 150 of the region's most innovative and energetic teachers, leaders, learners, and facilitators.

It featured a grassroots agenda that was built for the participants, by the participants, so it expanded in real-time as the RSVPs came rolling in.

Sessions ranged from the traditional planned and facilitated symposiums, to the impromptu Crash Camp discussion sessions, Choose Your Own Adventure!, Spark Sessions for Leaders & Teachers, Demo-Slam, App-y Hour, and Potluck P.D.

Back in April, Horace Greeley High School joined the Special Olympics New York Unified Champion Schools program, in partnership with NYSPHSAA.

The purpose of a Unified Sports team is to provide authentic, competitive opportunities for students with and without disabilities to participate in athletics. It was inspired by a simple principle: training together and playing together is a quick path to friendship and understanding, and active inclusion, acceptance, and respect through athletics provides educational benefits to all participants.

This inaugural season, the HG Unified Sports Co-Ed Basketball team tipped off against Hendrick Hudson, Pelham, John-Jay, and Fox Lane high schools. And although the season has come to an end, the meaningful friendships and fond memories of genuine athletic experiences and camaraderie are sure to last a lifetime.
